byline.contributor: Jo Becker reported from Cairo; Istanbul and Ankara, Turkey; Tunis; Paris; New York; and Washington, and Scott Shane from New York and Washington. Kitty Bennett contributed research.
byline.original: By JO BECKER and SCOTT SHANE

abstract: Hillary Clinton's role in convincing Pres Obama to support Libyan opposition, arguably her greatest moment of influence while secretary of state, provides clues as to what sort of president she might be and her approach to military action in Middle East; Clinton's position swayed fall of Libyan dictator Col Muammar el-Qaddafi and country's subsequent decline into terrorist haven, throwing her activist approach into question (Series: The Libya Gamble).

headline.print_headline: Clinton, ‘Smart Power’ and a Dictator’s Fall
headline.main: Hillary Clinton, ‘Smart Power’ and a Dictator’s Fall

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

snippet: The president was wary. The secretary of state was persuasive. But the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi left Libya a failed state and a terrorist haven.
lead_paragraph: The president was wary. The secretary of state was persuasive. But the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi left Libya a failed state and a terrorist haven.
